Threat: A malicious actor overloads the GPU with excessive requests, leading to denial of service
MITRE reference: EMB3D - TID-405 - Network Stack Resource Exhaustion

Threat: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in GPU drivers to execute arbitrary code
An attacker exploits weaknesses in the GPU’s memory management, causing data leakage
MITRE reference: EMB3D - TID-327 - Out of Bounds Memory Access

Threat: An attacker intercepts GPU communication channels, leading to unauthorized access or tampering
MITRE reference: EMB3D - TID-408 - Unencrypted Sensitive Data Communication

Threat: An unprivileged user is able to gain privileged access to vehicle systems
Attackers hijack drone control signals
MITRE reference: EMB3D - TID-105 - Hardware Fault Injection – Control Flow Modification

Threat: Attackers intercept video and data transmissions
MITRE reference: EMB3D - TID-406 - Unauthorized Messages or Connections

Threat: Attackers perform unauthorized physical tampering
MITRE reference: EMB3D - TID-107 - Unauthorized Direct Memory Access (DMA)

Threat: Code tampering
MITRE reference: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

Threat: Communication channels permit untrusted/unreliable messages to be accepted or are vulnerable to session hijacking/replay attacks
Communication channels used to conduct unauthorized manipulation, deletion or other amendments to vehicle held code/data
Cryptographic technologies can be compromised or are insufficiently applied
Data loss - data breach from vehicle
Data loss during migration
Data transmission interception
MITRE reference: EMB3D - TID-114 - Peripheral Data Bus Interception

Threat: Denial of service attacks via communication channels to disrupt vehicle functions
Devices connected to external interfaces e.g. USB ports, OBD port, used as a means to attack vehicle systems
Disruption of systems or operations
Environmental interference and EMI
MITRE reference: EMB3D - TID-105 - Hardware Fault Injection – Control Flow Modification

Threat: Erasure of data/code
Extraction of vehicle data/code
Hosted 3rd party software, e.g. entertainment applications, used as a means to attack vehicle systems
Inadequate key management
MITRE reference: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls

Threat: Information can be readily disclosed. For example, through eavesdropping on communications or through allowing unauthorized access to sensitive files or folders
Introduction of malware
Introduction of new software or overwrite existing software
It is possible to deny legitimate updates
Manipulation of the connectivity of vehicle functions enables a cyber-attack
Manipulation of vehicle data/code
Manipulation of vehicle parameters
Messages received by the vehicle (for example X2V or diagnostic messages), or transmitted within it, contain malicious content
Misuse or compromise of update procedures
Network design introduces vulnerabilities
Parts or supplies could be compromised to permit vehicles to be attacked
Physical manipulation of systems to enable an attack
Signal injection and manipulation
Software or hardware development permits vulnerabilities
Spoofing of messages or data received by the vehicle
Unauthorized access to device software
Unauthorized firmware updates are performed on the GPU, introducing malware or vulnerabilities
MITRE reference: EMB3D - TID-216 - Firmware Update Rollbacks Allowed

Threat: Unauthorized physical tampering
Unauthorized repository access
MITRE reference: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567.001 - Exfiltration to Code Repository

Threat: Unsecured over-the-air (OTA) updates
Viruses embedded in communication media are able to infect vehicle systems
